title: Detection of Intracranial Hemorrhage for Trauma Patients
authors:
Antoine P. Sanner, Nils F. Grauhan, Marc A. Brockmann, Ahmed E.
  Othman, Anirban Mukhopadhyay
abstract:
Whole-body CT is used for multi-trauma patients in the search of any and all
injuries. Since an initial assessment needs to be rapid and the search for
lesions is done for the whole body, very little time can be allocated for the
inspection of a specific anatomy. In particular, intracranial hemorrhages are
still missed, especially by clinical students. In this work, we present a Deep
Learning approach for highlighting such lesions to improve the diagnostic
accuracy. While most works on intracranial hemorrhages perform segmentation,
detection only requires bounding boxes for the localization of the bleeding. In
this paper, we propose a novel Voxel-Complete IoU (VC-IoU) loss that encourages
the network to learn the 3D aspect ratios of bounding boxes and leads to more
precise detections. We extensively experiment on brain bleeding detection using
a publicly available dataset, and validate it on a private cohort, where we
achieve 0.877 AR30, 0.728 AP30, and 0.653 AR30, 0.514 AP30 respectively. These
results constitute a relative +5% improvement in Average Recall for both
datasets compared to other loss functions. Finally, as there is little data
currently publicly available for 3D object detection and as annotation
resources are limited in the clinical setting, we evaluate the cost of
different annotation methods, as well as the impact of imprecise bounding boxes
in the training data on the detection performance.
subjects: Computing Research Repository/Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition
